name: Straw Man
definition: Misrepresenting someone's position to make it easier to attack.
whyItWorks: It's easier to defeat a caricature than a real argument. By exaggerating what someone said, we can 'win' against a version of their point that was never actually made.

examples.text: So you're saying I can never ask you to hang out? You just want to be alone forever?
examples.analysis: They said they needed some space this week, not that they never want to see you. Twisting their words makes it unfair.

examples.text: My parents say I spend too much time on my phone, so apparently they want me to have zero social life.
examples.analysis: Asking for less screen time isn't the same as wanting you isolated. The exaggeration avoids the real conversation.

examples.text: Cancel culture critics think people should be able to say anything with zero consequences.
examples.analysis: Most critics just want proportional responses, not zero accountability. The extreme version is easier to dismiss.

examples.text: Prison reformers want to let dangerous criminals walk free with no punishment.
examples.analysis: Most reformers focus on non-violent offenders and want rehabilitation alongside consequences, not eliminating accountability.

examples.text: Health skeptics think all natural supplements are snake oil and only trust Big Pharma.
examples.analysis: Most just want evidence-based claims. Wanting proof isn't the same as being anti-natural.

promptStarters: The other side wants us to believe that ___, which is ridiculous.
They basically think we should just ___.
So you're saying we should ___ and let ___ happen?
Their position is essentially that ___, which no sane person would support.
